newsitem.title: GERMANY: North Europe cocoa demand muted ahead of year-end.
newsitem.headline: North Europe cocoa demand muted ahead of year-end.

text.p: Cocoa consumers in continental northwest Europe were sidelined as London futures traded lower after Tuesday's rallies, traders said.
Physical markets were seen remaining quietly steady until early January.
"Business won't pick up unless prices fall dramatically and there are no reasons that they should," a German trader said.
"At the same time, the price upside appears limited by prospects of huge arrivals in West African ports once the current delays are overcome."
Raw materials buyers did not focus on cocoa supply fundamentals as chocolate plants were preoccupied with end-of-year production schedules and logistical disruptions.
Many manufacturers shut for maintenance during the December 20-January 4 fortnight and wind down raw materials purchases a few weeks in advance.
The French truck strike meant some butter cargoes did not get in and out of the country but this had no impact on prices.
Strike action at German confectionery plants was also ending after a few days of crisis as employers gave in to worker demands to maintain full sick pay arrangements.
London cocoa futures were down on profit-taking and origin sales while sterling was off its lows after tumbling from four-year highs on Tuesday.
March was down four stg at 940 at 1445 GMT.
Large-scale consumer buying was last seen in late November near the November 19 eight-months-lows of 903 stg on March.
Cocoa arrivals in Ivory Coast at the end of November were down an estimated 20 percent from last year at 285,000 tonnes because of rains in August/September, analysts said.
A Dutch trader said sellers used this to hike offers but buyers argued that arrivals should pick up in December and January.
Commenting on consumption, he noted fourth quarter chocolate production had run at high levels and grindings figures in early January should reflect this.
Cif Hamburg bean prices were at 2.32 marks/kg for December, up from 2.27 marks last week.
First quarter 1997 beans were at 2.35 marks versus 2.32.
The cocoa butter ratio was little changed at 2.70 up to March 1997, which implied prices liquid ex-works of 6.53 marks.
Sterling was fixed in Frankfurt on Wednesday at 2.5690 marks compared with 2.5558 marks a week ago.
